question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
Let \(u=x\) and \(dv = \cos x dx\). This gives \(du = dx\) and \(v = \sin x\). Hence, using integration by parts, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1}x\cos x \, dx &= x\sin x \mid_{0}^{1} - \int_{0}^{1}\sin x \, dx \\ &= (1)\sin(1) - (0)\sin(0) - (-\cos(x))|_{0}^{1} \\ &= \sin(1) - (-\cos(1) + \cos(0)) \\ &= \sin(1) + \cos(1) - 1\end{aligned}\]

completing the problem.
sols_latex:
Let $u=x$ and $dv = \cos x dx$. This gives $du = dx$ and $v = \sin x$.
Hence, using integration by parts, we have

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{1}x\cos x \, dx &= x\sin x \mid_{0}^{1} - \int_{0}^{1}\sin x \, dx \\
&= (1)\sin(1) - (0)\sin(0) - (-\cos(x))|_{0}^{1} \\
&= \sin(1) - (-\cos(1) + \cos(0)) \\
&= \sin(1) + \cos(1) - 1
\end{align*}

completing the problem.
